entry.title: Time Management Tips
entry.content:
Why try to improve your time management?

  • Manage the stress of the overwhelming crush of task
  • Feel confident that you‚Äôve been working on what‚Äôs important
  • Feel greater ease when leaving work at the end of the day

What are the constraints on your time?

You‚Äôve got limited time at work each day say about 8 hours excluding lunch. Of that time you might have about 2 hours of meetings on average (data pulled from clockwise). Heading to and from meetings, starting work and stopping work are all going to take time as well. Say another hour of time.

So you‚Äôre maybe looking at 5 or fewer hours to get it all done. But then on top of that it‚Äôs hard to stay focused more than 30 min and you get sleepy in the afternoon!

When faced with limited time one solution is to simply work longer hours. Sometimes this is unavoidable however it‚Äôs rarely sustainable. Better is to maximize the amount of productive time available and then to use it efficiently.

How to maximize the amount of productive time

Don‚Äôt let meetings control your life.

  • Minimize meetings by asking yourself critically if you are really needed. Seeing an agenda beforehand can help you understand if you are needed. Alternatively can you contribute asynchronously or attend only part of the meeting?
  • Try to group meetings together. This allows you to maximize larger chunks of time for heads down focused efforts. Tools like Clockwise can automatically move meetings for you.

Guard your most productive hours.

  • You may find you‚Äôre most productive in the morning or perhaps at the end of the day. Whatever it is it is worth putting a block on your calendar and trying to protect that time.
  • You can set your working hours in google calendar to help block off those hours and Clockwise can help with this as well.

How to make the best of the available time

Work on the most important thing first.

  • At the beginning of your day pick the most important thing. Then do that before thinking about anything else. This strategy is simple and therefore a good place to start.
  • This is sometimes called Eat the Frog and is based on how humans tend to work. Getting a key task done gives you momentum and picking just one thing helps you combat inherent optimism about how much can truly be done in a day.

Beware the interruptions.

  • When you‚Äôre heading into your productive time set yourself up for success. A quieter environment is good whether attained through headphones or changing location.
  • Notifications can be silenced by setting work hours on your Mac and by setting do not disturb in Slack. I sometimes find it helpful to actually close Slack when I need to focus.
  • Hide your phone!

During long stretches of work take deliberate breaks to stay sharp.

  • Humans tend to maintain focus on a task for about 30 min but pretty soon our eyes and mind tire. At this point it‚Äôs worth taking a little break to recoup.
  • During your breaks avoid screens so as to rest your eyes. For example getting water, going to the bathroom, stretching or doing a quick house chore might work for you.
  • Methods like Pomodoro can help you manage these time intervals (Pomofocus, TogglTrack, Be Focused Timer).

How to Keep Track of it All Don‚Äôt try to keep it all in your head.

  • Tons of little things will come at you during the day. You‚Äôre only physically capable of remembering about 7 of them so rather than fight the chaos write down these tasks as they come.
  • By writing things down you give yourself a chance to process and decide what is actually important.
  • There are a ton of tools to help you with this. Feel free to experiment and see what works for you: Remember the Milk, Todo.txt, Orgmode, Trello, Asana, Roam, Notion

Prioritize what is important instead of urgent.

  • ‚ÄúI have two kinds of problems, the urgent and the important. The urgent are not important, and the important are never urgent.‚Äù - Eisenhower (possibly)
  • Urgent things like Slack messages can feel important but rarely are.
  • When looking at your tasks there will be some things that are important and urgent that need doing first after those are done you should ideally be spending most of your time on longer term important tasks.

It is ok not to get everything done. That isn‚Äôt the goal.

  • You will rarely get everything in your list done in any given day. That is ok because your time is limited and you‚Äôve hopefully been doing the important stuff first.
  • Periodically you‚Äôll want to clear out old tasks which are likely no longer important.
  • If you‚Äôre constantly stretched and find that you‚Äôre not getting important stuff done that is a sign that you need to be changing something. Say no to more work and let people know you‚Äôll be dropping the ball on things.

Debugging Your Time

You probably don‚Äôt know where your time goes.

  • Periodically it can be really informative to perform a time study. This will let you see in detail where your time goes and allows you to decide if you‚Äôre really doing what you want with this limited resource.
  • I recommend committing to recording your time usage every 30 min for a typical week to get a sense of where your time goes.
  • Tools like TogglTrack or a simple spreadsheet can help.

Procrastination isn‚Äôt about being bad at time management.

  • Procrastination is likely a way for you to avoid tough emotions rather than a personal failure.
  • If you find yourself procrastinating it may be a good chance to ask yourself how you‚Äôre feeling about the task. Is it scary? Are you worried about failure? Forgive yourself for the procrastination and seek to address the underlying emotion. Meditation can help a lot. The NYTimes has a great piece on this. NPR does too.
  • Catching yourself when you start procrastinating is hard but there are some tools to help like RescueTime and iOS and Android app time limits. Mac also has Screen Time settings in system preferences.

A Summary of Weekly Practices

On Monday morning

  • Look at your calendar and ask if you really need to attend all those meetings.
  • Block out focus time on your calendar proactively.

Each morning

  • What‚Äôs the one important thing to do today. Start on that.

During the day

  • Add tasks to your tracker as they come.
  • Reprioritize tasks as you check things off.

Periodically

  • Reevaluate your system because your current tools may no longer be working for you.
  • Remove old tasks from your tracking system.

Further Reading

  • Wikipedia on time management tools
entry.summary: A summary of time management tips I've taught at various jobs

entry.title: Engineering Manager Readme
entry.content:
Motivation for this document

This document outlines how I operate as a software engineering manager (EM). My hope is to give you a sense for how I approach the job and what working with me would be like. I‚Äôve served as an engineering manager at Branch International, Digit, KoBold Metals & Klaviyo.

If you‚Äôre just looking for the TLDR:

  • I aim to be a servant leader, empowering others to succeed
  • I value continuous learning and improvement
  • I like to build teams based on trust, accountability, respect & a clear mission

ü•ñ My role

As an EM, my job is to empower folks so that as a team we can collectively make a strong impact. I do that by growing teams that are built around a clear shared vision, trust, accountability and respectful communication processes.

In this job, my focus varies depending on the company‚Äôs needs. If the company is hiring, I debug the recruiting process and conduct numerous interviews. When new team members join, I teach technical skills, provide learning opportunities and regularly check in with them. During planning periods, I collect stakeholder needs and collaborate with product teams on a roadmap. Throughout these activities, I assist, establish processes, and train others to strengthen the organization over time.

While many activities shift, there are a few things I‚Äôm always doing: creating a safe environment at the company for everyone to do their best work and helping people find avenues for growth in their careers. Sometimes that‚Äôs resolving conflicts, taking time to ensure everyone‚Äôs communication styles are empowered or providing feedback on a career plan. In all this work, I seek to empower folks with the skills and confidence they need to be successful independently.

üìê How am I measured?

In my role as a manager I‚Äôm measured in a few ways:

  • Hiring processes that result in successful hires quickly
  • Onboarding processes that result in new people contributing quickly
  • Career growth support so that people stay on the team and increase their impact over time in a fulfilling way
  • Team success in estimating and completing quarterly goals
  • Contributions to the overall organization and engineering team that improve collaboration, efficiency, retention or other important metrics

üìö What do I value most?

‚ôªÔ∏è Continuous improvement & learning

Continually learning and growing is the most important thing to me. In life and the working world, change is constant, people are unique and so staying curious, humble and open-minded is key.

Whether personally or within the team, I find a few ingredients are necessary for continuous improvement to take place:

  • Consistent, deliberate introspection like sprint retros and my weekly self-reflection
  • Feedback loops, both quantitative and qualitative from customers, peers & systems
  • Humility to be open to new ideas
  • Empathy to listen and understand others
  • Making space for learning and research in your schedule and roadmap

üéâ Feedback, especially celebration

This is part of continuous improvement but worth calling out explicitly. This is a value learned from experience: constructive feedback is important but not as strong a tool for change as positive reinforcement. Celebrating team wins, constructive behaviors and setting a good example all push a team along much faster than criticism.

I like to use Situation, Behavior, Impact, Pause as a framing when giving feedback. I believe in prompt and private feedback when it‚Äôs constructive. And I like to celebrate positive things more in public based on the individual or team‚Äôs preferences.

ü§î Deliberate decision making

I value a strong communication process around decision making. For reversible decisions, I appreciate fast, data-based decisions. For hard to rollback decisions, I appreciate deliberation, research and experimentation. For any decision, I believe in defining roles upfront using frameworks like DACI (driver, approver, contributor, informed) and setting clear objectives around problems being solved and the definition of done.

üò† How I manage conflict

I tend towards collaborative, mediated and systems oriented conflict resolution.

  • I seek to lower the temperature right away for example by bringing the conflict into 1-1 or smaller group conversations
  • I listen without judgment to all parties involved
  • I aim to understand the whole person including if there are external stressors
  • I try to understand everyone‚Äôs roles and goals so I know how they are framing the problem
  • I hope to be a curious and respectful mediator
  • If possible, I aim to empower people to work through the conflict rather than dictating a resolution

üëç My expectations from the team

  • You‚Äôve got a learning mindset. You‚Äôre game to learn, grow and open to change.
  • You own your career. I can support, provide feedback and open doors but at the end of the day you decide where you want to go next and on what timeline.
  • You are accountable for the work you commit to. You share when you‚Äôre blocked or behind with the team promptly and you make sure your stakeholders are informed.
  • You take ownership in the team and company‚Äôs success. You take initiative to surface or fix issues even if they are outside of your normal duties.
  • You are respectful of your coworkers and customers and assume best intentions from everyone else.

üí¨ How I run 1-1s

  • Consistent schedule so we always have time to talk
  • We take time to connect as humans
  • We focus on discussing challenges and career development
  • We avoid status updates which should ideally happen in other settings
  • I make space for upward feedback and ask for feedback on specific things
  • I recognize your wins and what‚Äôs going well consistently
  • I share constructive feedback promptly

üèóÔ∏è What your first 90 days would look like

Here are some key elements of my 30/60/90 day process! This plan is more tailored to software engineering. The idea is to start small, focus on building connections first, contribute small code changes and own a larger feature within the first few months.

Some general advice

  • Take copious notes since you‚Äôll forget most information coming your way.
  • Ask questions, this is your time to learn as much as possible!
  • Focus on your onboarding, not on finding ways to contribute right away. You‚Äôll be most effective later if you learn now.
  • Focus on learning people and culture over technical details since relationship building takes time.
  • As you get further on aim for small wins within your wheelhouse and don‚Äôt overcommit right away.
  • Be kind to yourself: you were hired for a reason and you‚Äôre not expected to be effective at your job for a number of months!

Immediately

  • Meet the team
  • Meet your onboarding buddy
  • Meet your manager
  • Get full context on the state of the world and systems in play
  • Wrap your head around what‚Äôs on the team roadmap
  • Participate in company onboarding meetings
  • While onboarding: update docs, take notes, ask questions!

First month

  • Participate in engineering and team onboarding meetings
  • Meet the key leaders and peers outside of your team
  • Get setup and contribute small changes to the codebase
  • Get up to speed on your first larger project
  • Participate in team activities like code review, sprint planning, etc.
  • Find any fun groups you‚Äôd like to connect with like an ERG or the pet parents club
  • Brainstorm with your manager on career paths

First quarter

  • Ship your first feature contribution!
  • Be up to speed on the various product initiatives and participate in quarterly team brainstorming and planning
  • Start to participate in recruiting
  • Develop a career plan and personal goals
  • Write-up your thoughts and feedback on onboarding and how the company/team is doing. A framework to organize things can be strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats.

üòú My quirks and other things to know about me

I struggle with

I can sometimes ramble or talk too much in meetings. Feel free to cut me off or let me know afterwards!

How I like my feedback

I prefer feedback in private, verbally and am ok with public praise.

How I process information

I tend to process information visually so you‚Äôll see me taking notes in meetings for example. I also bias towards having a decision document rather than a series of meetings. I also love well labeled charts!

I have little patience for

I have less patience for ego, people talking over each other, meetings without agendas and negativity, especially when it‚Äôs about other people.

How I focus

I‚Äôm best able to focus in a quiet environment where I can be distraction free for a spell. You may see me log off slack sometimes if I need time to get a project done. I‚Äôll also schedule work blocks and I try to cluster my meetings using tools like Clockwise.

üìñ Resources I constantly reference

  • Atlassian playbooks for team activities
  • Will Larson‚Äôs blog
  • The Manager‚Äôs Path by Camille Fournier
entry.summary: My leadership philosophy and management style.
